tool.name: SaQC
tool.description: quality control pipelines for environmental sensor data
tool.command: #if str($run_test_mode) == "true": '$__tool_directory__'/json_to_saqc_config.py '$param_conf' > config.csv #else '$__tool_directory__'/json_to_saqc_config.py '$param_conf' > config.csv && #for $i, $d in enumerate($data) ln -s '$d' '${i}.csv' && #end for saqc --config config.csv #for $i, $d in enumerate($data) --data '${i}.csv' #end for --outfile output.csv #end if

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: flagIsolated: Find and flag temporal isolated groups of data
flagJumps: Flag jumps and drops in data

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Minimum gap size required before and after a data group to consider it isolated
param.help: See condition (2) and (3)

param.label: Maximum size of a data chunk to consider it a candidate for an isolated group
param.help: Data chunks that are bigger than the `group_window` are ignored. This does not include the possible gaps surrounding it. See condition (1)

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Threshold value by which the mean of data has to jump, to trigger flagging
param.help: Threshold value by which the mean of data has to jump, to trigger flagging

param.label: Size of the two moving windows
param.help: This determines the number of observations used for calculating the mean in every window. The window size should be big enough to yield enough samples for a reliable mean calculation, but it should also not be arbitrarily big, since it also limits the density of jumps that can be detected. More precisely: Jumps that are not distanced to each other by more than three fourth (3/4) of the selected `window` size, will not be detected reliably

param.label: min_periods
param.help: The minimum number of observations in `window` required to calculate a valid mean value

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: dfilter
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional Defines which observations will be masked based on the already existing flags. Any data point with a flag equal or worse to this threshold will be passed as ``NaN`` to the function. Defaults to the ``DFILTER_ALL`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: dfilter
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional Defines which observations will be masked based on the already existing flags. Any data point with a flag equal or worse to this threshold will be passed as ``NaN`` to the function. Defaults to the ``DFILTER_ALL`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: assignChangePointCluster: Label data where it changes significantly
flagChangePoints: Flag values that represent a system state transition

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: A function that assigns a value to every twin window
param.help: Left window content will be passed to first variable, right window content will be passed to the second

param.label: thresh_func
param.help: A function that determines the value level, exceeding wich qualifies a timestamps func value as denoting a changepoint

conditional.name: window_cond
conditional.label: Size of the rolling windows the calculation is performed in

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the rolling windows the calculation is performed in'
param.help: If it is a single frequency offset, it applies for the backward- and the forward-facing window. If two offsets (as a tuple) is passed the first defines the size of the backward facing window, the second the size of the forward facing window

param.name: min_periods_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'min_periods'
param.help: Minimum number of observations in a window required to perform the changepoint test. If it is a tuple of two int, the first refer to the backward-, the second to the forward-facing window

param.label: reduce_window
param.help: The sliding window search method is not an exact CP search method and usually there won't be detected a single changepoint, but a region of change around a changepoint. If `reduce_window` is given, for every window of size `reduce_window`, there will be selected the value with index `reduce_func(x, y)` and the others will be dropped. If `reduce_window` is None, the reduction window size equals the twin window size, the changepoints have been detected with

param.label: reduce_func
param.help: default argmax A function that must return an index value upon input of two arrays x and y. First input parameter will hold the result from the stat_func evaluation for every reduction window. Second input parameter holds the result from the thresh_func evaluation. The default reduction function just selects the value that maximizes the stat_func

param.label: If True, the results of `stat_funcs` are written, otherwise the regime labels
param.help: If True, the results of `stat_funcs` are written, otherwise the regime labels

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: A function that assigns a value to every twin window
param.help: The backward-facing window content will be passed as the first array, the forward-facing window content as the second

param.label: thresh_func
param.help: A function that determines the value level, exceeding wich qualifies a timestamps func value as denoting a change-point

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the moving windows'
param.help: This is the number of observations used for calculating the statistic. If it is a single frequency offset, it applies for the backward- and the forward-facing window. If two offsets (as a tuple) is passed the first defines the size of the backward facing window, the second the size of the forward facing window

param.name: min_periods_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'min_periods'
param.help: Minimum number of observations in a window required to perform the changepoint test. If it is a tuple of two int, the first refer to the backward-, the second to the forward-facing window

param.label: reduce_window
param.help: The sliding window search method is not an exact CP search method and usually there wont be detected a single changepoint, but a region of change around a changepoint. If `reduce_window` is given, for every window of size `reduce_window`, there will be selected the value with index `reduce_func(x, y)` and the others will be dropped. If `reduce_window` is None, the reduction window size equals the twin window size, the changepoints have been detected with

param.label: reduce_func
param.help: default argmax A function that must return an index value upon input of two arrays x and y. First input parameter will hold the result from the stat_func evaluation for every reduction window. Second input parameter holds the result from the `thresh_func` evaluation. The default reduction function just selects the value that maximizes the `stat_func`

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Size of the moving window
param.help: This is the number of observations used for calculating the statistic. Each window will be a fixed size. If its an offset then this will be the time period of each window. Each window will be sized, based on the number of observations included in the time-period

param.label: Maximum total variance allowed per window
param.help: Maximum total variance allowed per window

param.label: Maximum number of NaNs allowed in window
param.help: If more NaNs are present, the window is not flagged

param.label: Same as `maxna` but for consecutive NaNs
param.help: Same as `maxna` but for consecutive NaNs

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Maximum total change allowed per window
param.help: Maximum total change allowed per window

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the moving window'
param.help: This determines the number of observations used for calculating the absolute change per window. Each window will either contain a fixed number of periods (integer defined window), or will have a fixed temporal extension (offset defined window)

param.label: Minimum number of observations in window required to generate a flag
param.help: This can be used to exclude underpopulated *offset* defined windows from flagging. (Integer defined windows will always contain exactly *window* samples). Must be an integer greater or equal `2`, because a single value would always be considered constant. Defaults to `2`

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: fitLowpassFilter: Fits the data using the butterworth filter
fitMomentFM: Fits the data by reconstructing it with the Moment Foundational Timeseries Model (MomentFM)
fitPolynomial: Fits a polynomial model to the data

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: cutoff_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'cutoff'
param.help: The cutoff-frequency, either an offset freq string, or expressed in multiples of the sampling rate

param.label: The niquist-frequency
param.help: expressed in multiples if the sampling rate

param.label: fill_method
param.help: Fill method to be applied on the data before filtering (butterfilter cant handle ''np.nan''). See documentation of pandas.Series.interpolate method for details on the methods associated with the different keywords

param.name: field_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Variable to process'
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: The number of samples generated for any values reconstruction
param.help: Must be a divisor of `context`. Effectively controlls the stride-width of the reconstruction window through the data

param.label: context
param.help: size of the context window with regard to wich any value is reconstructed

param.label: How to aggregate the different reconstructions for the same value
param.help: * 'center': use the value that was constructed in a window centering around the origin value * 'mean': assign the mean over all reconstructed values * 'median': assign the median over all reconstructed values * 'std': assign the standard deviation over all reconstructed values

repeat.name: model_spec
repeat.title: model_spec
repeat.help: Dictionary with the fields: * `pretrained_model_name_or_path` * `revision` Defaults to global Parameter `DEFAULT_MOMENT=dict(pretrained_model_name_or_path= AutonLab/MOMENT-1-large , revision= main `

param.name: key
param.label: Key
param.help: Name of the dictionary key.

param.name: value
param.label: Value
param.help: Value for the key (e.g., 'min,max').

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

conditional.name: window_cond
conditional.label: Size of the window you want to use for fitting

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the window you want to use for fitting'
param.help: If an integer is passed, the size refers to the number of periods for every fitting window. If an offset string is passed, the size refers to the total temporal extension. The window will be centered around the vaule-to-be-fitted. For regularly sampled data always a odd number of periods will be used for the fit (periods-1 if periods is even)

param.label: Degree of the polynomial used for fitting
param.help: Degree of the polynomial used for fitting

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Minimum number of observations in a window required to perform the fit, otherwise NaNs will be assigned. If ``None``, `min_periods` defaults to 1 for integer windows and to the size of the window for offset based windows. Passing 0, disables the feature and will result in over-fitting for too sparse windows

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: assignRegimeAnomaly: A function to detect values belonging to an anomalous regime regarding modelling
correctDrift: The function corrects drifting behavior
correctRegimeAnomaly: Function fits the passed model to the different regimes in data[field] and tries to correct
flagDriftFromNorm: Flags data that deviates from an avarage data course
flagDriftFromReference: Flags data that deviates from a reference course. Deviation is measured by a
flagRegimeAnomaly: Flags anomalous regimes regarding to modelling regimes of ``field``

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Column in data, holding the cluster labels for the samples in field
param.help: (has to be indexed equal to field)

param.label: A threshold denoting the value level, up to wich clusters a agglomerated
param.help: A threshold denoting the value level, up to wich clusters a agglomerated

param.label: The linkage method for hierarchical (agglomerative) clustering of the variables
param.help: The linkage method for hierarchical (agglomerative) clustering of the variables

param.label: A metric function for calculating the dissimilarity between 2 regimes
param.help: Defaults to the absolute difference in mean

param.label: frac
param.help: The minimum percentage of samples, the normal group has to comprise to actually be the normal group. Must be in the closed interval `[0,1]`, otherwise a ValueError is raised

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Column holding the support-points information
param.help: The data is expected to have the following form: The index of the series represents the beginning of a maintenance event, wheras the values represent its endings

conditional.name: model_cond
conditional.label: A model function describing the drift behavior, that is to be corrected

param.name: model_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'A model function describing the drift behavior, that is to be corrected'
param.help: Either use built-in exponential or linear drift model by passing a string, or pass a custom callable. The model function must always contain the keyword parameters 'origin' and 'target'. The starting parameter must always be the parameter, by wich the data is passed to the model. After the data parameter, there can occure an arbitrary number of model calibration arguments in the signature. See the Notes section for an extensive description

param.label: cal_range
param.help: Number of values to calculate the mean of, for obtaining the value level directly after and directly before a maintenance event. Needed for shift calibration

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: max_jump
param.help: when searching for changepoints in mean - this is the threshold a mean difference in the sliding window search must exceed to trigger changepoint detection

param.label: spread
param.help: threshold denoting the maximum, regimes are allowed to abolutely differ in their means to form the normal group of values

param.label: Size of the adjacent windows that are used to search for the mean changepoints
param.help: Size of the adjacent windows that are used to search for the mean changepoints

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Minimum number of periods a search window has to contain, for the result of the changepoint detection to be considered valid

param.label: tolerance
param.help: If an offset string is passed, a data chunk of length `offset` right from the start and right before the end of any regime is ignored when calculating a regimes mean for data correcture. This is to account for the unrelyability of data near the changepoints of regimes

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: cluster_field
param.help: A string denoting the field in data, holding the cluster label for the data you want to correct

param.label: The model function to be fitted to the regimes
param.help: It must be a function of the form :math:`f(x, *p)`, where :math:`x` is the ``numpy.array`` holding the independent variables and :math:`p` are the model parameters that are to be obtained by fitting. Depending on the `x_date` parameter, independent variable x will either be the timestamps of every regime transformed to seconds from epoch, or it will be just seconds, counting the regimes length

param.label: tolerance
param.help: If an offset string is passed, a data chunk of length `offset` right at the start and right at the end is ignored when fitting the model. This is to account for the unreliability of data near the changepoints of regimes. Defaults to None

param.label: epoch
param.help: If True, use seconds from epoch as x input to the model func, instead of seconds from regime start

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Frequency, that split the data in chunks
param.help: Frequency, that split the data in chunks

param.label: Maximum spread allowed in the group of *normal* data
param.help: See Notes section for more details

param.label: Fraction defining the normal group
param.help: Use a value from the interval [0,1]. The higher the value, the more stable the algorithm will be. For values below 0.5 the results are undefined

param.label: metric
param.help: default cityblock Distance function that takes two arrays as input and returns a scalar float. This value is interpreted as the distance of the two input arrays. Defaults to the `averaged manhattan metric` (see Notes)

param.label: Linkage method used for hierarchical (agglomerative) clustering of the data
param.help: `method` is directly passed to ``scipy.hierarchy.linkage``. See its documentation [1] for more details. For a general introduction on hierarchical clustering see [2]

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Reference variable, the deviation is calculated from
param.help: Reference variable, the deviation is calculated from

param.label: Frequency, that split the data in chunks
param.help: Frequency, that split the data in chunks

param.label: Maximum deviation from reference
param.help: Maximum deviation from reference

param.label: metric
param.help: default cityblock Distance function. Takes two arrays as input and returns a scalar float. This value is interpreted as the mutual distance of the two input arrays. Defaults to the `averaged manhattan metric` (see Notes)

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Column in data, holding the cluster labels for the samples in field
param.help: (has to be indexed equal to field)

param.label: A threshold denoting the value level, up to wich clusters a agglomerated
param.help: A threshold denoting the value level, up to wich clusters a agglomerated

param.label: The linkage method for hierarchical (agglomerative) clustering of the variables
param.help: The linkage method for hierarchical (agglomerative) clustering of the variables

param.label: A metric function for calculating the dissimilarity between 2 regimes
param.help: Defaults to the absolute difference in mean

param.label: frac
param.help: The minimum percentage of samples, the normal group has to comprise to actually be the normal group. Must be in the closed interval `[0,1]`, otherwise a ValueError is raised

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: andGroup: Logical AND operation for Flags
clearFlags: Assign UNFLAGGED value to all periods in field
flagDummy: Function does nothing but returning data and flags
flagManual: Include flags listed in external data
flagUnflagged: Function sets a flag at all unflagged positions
forceFlags: Set whole column to a flag value
orGroup: Logical OR operation for Flags
propagateFlags: Flag values before or after flags set by the last test
transferFlags: Transfer Flags of one variable to another

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: group
param.label: A collection of ``SaQC`` objects
param.help: Flag checks are performed on all ``SaQC`` objects based on the variables specified in ``field``. Whenever all monitored variables are flagged, the associated timestamps will receive a flag

param.label: target
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` , optional Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

conditional.name: mdata_cond
conditional.label: Determines which values or intervals will be flagged

param.name: mdata_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Determines which values or intervals will be flagged'
param.help: Supported input types: * ``pd.Series``: Needs a datetime index and values of type: - datetime, for `method` values `` right-closed ``, `` left-closed ``, `` closed `` - or any scalar, for `method` values `` plain ``, `` ontime `` * ``str``: Variable holding the manual flag information. * ``pd.DataFrame``, ``DictOfSeries``: Need to provide a ``pd.Series`` with column name `field`. * ``list``, ``np.ndarray``: Only supported with `method` value `` plain `` and `mformat` value `` mflag ``

param.label: method
param.help: Defines how `mdata` is projected to data: * `` plain ``: `mdata` must have the same length as `field`, flags are set, where the values in `mdata` equal `mflag`. * `` ontime ``: Expects datetime indexed `mdata` (types ``pd.Series``, ``pd.DataFrame``, ``DictOfSeries``). Flags are set, where the values in `mdata` equal `mflag` and the indices of `field` and `mdata` match. * `` right-open ``: Expects datetime indexed `mdata`, which will be interpreted as a number of time intervals ``t_1, t_2``. Flags are set to all timestamps ``t`` of `field` with ``t_1 = t t_2``. * `` left-open ``: like `` right-open ``, but the interval covers all ``t`` with ``t_1 t = t_2``. * `` closed ``: like `` right-open ``, but the interval now covers all ``t`` with ``t_1 = t = t_2``

param.label: mformat
param.help: Controls the interval definition in `mdata` (see examples): * `` start-end ``: expects datetime indexed `mdata` (types ``pd.Series``, ``pd.DataFrame``, ``DictOfSeries``) with values of type datetime. Each index-value pair is interpreted as an interval to flag, the index defines the left bound, the respective value the right bound. * `` mflag ``: - `mdata` of type ``pd.Series``, ``pd.DataFrame``, ``DictOfSeries``: Two successive index values ``i_1, i_2`` will be interpreted as an interval ``t_1, t_2`` to flag, if the value of ``t_1`` equals `mflag` - `mdata` of type ``list``, ``np.ndarray``: Flags all `field` where `mdata` euqals `mflag`

param.label: mflag
param.help: Value in `mdata` indicating that a flag should be set at the respective position, timestamp or interval. Ignored if `mformat` is set to `` start-end ``

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: group
param.label: A collection of ``SaQC`` objects
param.help: Flag checks are performed on all ``SaQC`` objects based on the variables specified in `field`. Whenever any of monitored variables is flagged, the associated timestamps will receive a flag

param.label: target
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` , optional Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the repetition window'
param.help: An integer defines the exact number of repetitions, strings are interpreted as time offsets to fill with

param.label: Direction of repetetion
param.help: With ffill the subsequent values receive the flag to repeat, with bfill the previous values

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: dfilter
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional Defines which observations will be masked based on the already existing flags. Any data point with a flag equal or worse to this threshold will be passed as ``NaN`` to the function. Defaults to the ``DFILTER_ALL`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: target_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'target'
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` , optional Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: squeeze
param.help: Squeeze the history into a single column if ``True``, function specific flag information is lost

param.label: Overwrite existing flags if ``True``
param.help: Overwrite existing flags if ``True``

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: flagGeneric: Flag data based on a given function
processGeneric: Generate/process data with user defined functions

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Function to call
param.help: The function needs to accept the same number of arguments (of type pandas.Series) as variables given in ``field`` and return an iterable of array-like objects of data type ``bool`` with the same length as ``target``

param.name: target_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'target'
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` , optional Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Function to call on the variables given in ``field``
param.help: The return value will be written to ``target`` or ``field`` if the former is not given. This implies, that the function needs to accept the same number of arguments (of type pandas.Series) as variables given in ``field`` and should return an iterable of array-like objects with the same number of elements as given in ``target`` (or ``field`` if ``target`` is not specified)

param.name: target_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'target'
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` , optional Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: dfilter
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional Defines which observations will be masked based on the already existing flags. Any data point with a flag equal or worse to this threshold will be passed as ``NaN`` to the function. Defaults to the ``DFILTER_ALL`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: align: Convert time series to specified frequency. Values affected by
interpolateByRolling: Replace NaN by the aggregation result of the surrounding window

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: freq_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Target frequency'
param.help: Target frequency

param.label: Interpolation technique to use
param.help: One of: * ``'nshift'``: Shift grid points to the nearest time stamp in the range = +/- 0.5 * ``freq``. * ``'bshift'``: Shift grid points to the first succeeding time stamp (if any). * ``'fshift'``: Shift grid points to the last preceeding time stamp (if any). * ``'linear'``: Ignore the index and treat the values as equally spaced. * ``'time'``, ``'index'``, ``'values'``: Use the actual numerical values of the index. * ``'pad'``: Fill in NaNs using existing values. * ``'spline'``, ``'polynomial'``: Passed to ``scipy.interpolate.interp1d``. These methods use the numerical values of the index. An ``order`` must be specified, e.g. ``qc.interpolate(method='polynomial', order=5)``. * ``'nearest'``, ``'zero'``, ``'slinear'``, ``'quadratic'``, ``'cubic'``, ``'barycentric'``: Passed to ``scipy.interpolate.interp1d``. These methods use the numerical values of the index. * ``'krogh'``, ``'spline'``, ``'pchip'``, ``'akima'``, ``'cubicspline'``: Wrappers around the SciPy interpolation methods of similar names. * ``'from_derivatives'``: Refers to ``scipy.interpolate.BPoly.from_derivatives``

param.label: order
param.help: Order of the interpolation method, ignored if not supported by the chosen ``method``

param.label: If set to `True`, existing flags will be cleared
param.help: If set to `True`, existing flags will be cleared

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

conditional.name: window_cond
conditional.label: The size of the window, the aggregation is computed from

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'The size of the window, the aggregation is computed from'
param.help: An integer define the number of periods to be used, a string is interpreted as an offset. ( see `pandas.rolling` for more information). Integer windows may result in screwed aggregations if called on none-harmonized or irregular data

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'func'
param.help: default median The function used for aggregation

param.label: Center the window around the value
param.help: Can only be used with integer windows, otherwise it is silently ignored

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Minimum number of valid (not np.nan) values that have to be available in a window for its aggregation to be computed

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: flagByScatterLowpass: Flag data chunks of length ``window`` dependent on the data deviation
flagByStatLowPass: Flag data chunks of length ``window`` dependent on the data deviation

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'window'
param.help: Window (i.e. chunk) size

validator.message: Please enter a valid Timedelta string (e.g., '30min', '2H', '1D').

param.label: thresh
param.help: Threshold. A given chunk is flagged, if the return value of ``func`` excceeds ``thresh``

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'func'
param.help: Either a string, determining the aggregation function applied on every chunk: * 'std': standard deviation * 'var': variance * 'mad': median absolute deviation Or a Callable, mapping 1 dimensional array likes onto scalars

param.name: sub_window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'sub_window'
param.help: Window size of sub chunks, that are additionally tested for exceeding ``sub_thresh`` with respect to ``func``

validator.message: Please enter a valid Timedelta string (e.g., '30min', '2H', '1D').

param.label: sub_thresh
param.help: Threshold. A given sub chunk is flagged, if the return value of ``func` excceeds ``sub_thresh``

param.label: Minimum number of values needed in a chunk to perfom the test
param.help: Ignored if ``window`` is an integer

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'func'
param.help: Either a String value, determining the aggregation function applied on every chunk. * 'std': standard deviation * 'var': variance * 'mad': median absolute deviation Or a Callable function mapping 1 dimensional arraylikes onto scalars. window : Window (i.e. chunk) size. thresh : Threshold. A given chunk is flagged, if the return value of ``func`` excceeds ``thresh``. sub_window : Window size of sub chunks, that are additionally tested for exceeding ``sub_thresh`` with respect to ``func``. sub_thresh : Threshold. A given sub chunk is flagged, if the return value of ``func` excceeds ``sub_thresh``. min_periods : Minimum number of values needed in a chunk to perfom the test. Ignored if ``window`` is an integer

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: flagByGrubbs: Flag outliers using the Grubbs algorithm
flagByStray: Flag outliers in 1-dimensional (score) data using the STRAY Algorithm
flagLOF: Flag values where the Local Outlier Factor (LOF) exceeds cutoff
flagMAD: Flag outliers using the modified Z-score outlier detection method
flagMVScores: The algorithm implements a 3-step outlier detection procedure for
flagOffset: A basic outlier test that works on regularly and irregularly sampled data
flagRaise: The function flags raises and drops in value courses, that exceed a certain threshold within a certain timespan
flagRange: Function flags values exceeding the closed
flagUniLOF: Flag univariate Local Outlier Factor (LOF) exceeding cutoff
flagZScore: Flag data where its (rolling) Zscore exceeds a threshold

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the testing window'
param.help: If an integer, the fixed number of observations used for each window. If an offset string the time period of each window

param.label: Level of significance, the grubbs test is to be performed at
param.help: Must be between 0 and 1

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Minimum number of values needed in a `window` in order to perform the grubs test. Ignored if `window` is an integer

param.label: If ``True``, every value gets checked twice
param.help: First in the initial rolling `window` and second in a rolling window that is lagging by `window` / 2. Recommended to avoid false positives at the window edges. Ignored if `window` is an offset string

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'window'
param.help: Determines the segmentation of the data into partitions, the kNN algorithm is applied onto individually. * ``None``: Apply Scoring on whole data set at once * ``int``: Apply scoring on successive data chunks of periods with the given length. Must be greater than 0. * offset String : Apply scoring on successive partitions of temporal extension matching the passed offset string

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Minimum number of periods per partition that have to be present for a valid outlier detection to be made in this partition

param.label: iter_start
param.help: Float in ``[0, 1]`` that determines which percentage of data is considered normal . ``0.5`` results in the stray algorithm to search only the upper 50% of the scores for the cut off point. (See reference section for more information)

param.label: alpha
param.help: Level of significance by which it is tested, if a score might be drawn from another distribution than the majority of the data

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: field_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Variable to process'
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Number of neighbors to be included into the LOF calculation
param.help: Defaults to ``20``, which is a value found to be suitable in the literature. * `n` determines the locality of an observation (its `n` nearest neighbors) and sets the upper limit to the number of values in outlier clusters (i.e. consecutive outliers). Outlier clusters of size greater than `n`/2 may not be detected reliably. * The larger `n`, the lesser the algorithm's sensitivity to local outliers and small or singleton outliers points. Higher values greatly increase numerical costs

conditional.name: thresh_cond
conditional.label: The threshold for flagging the calculated LOF

param.name: thresh_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'The threshold for flagging the calculated LOF'
param.help: A LOF of around ``1`` is considered normal and most likely corresponds to inlier points. * The automatic threshing introduced with the publication of the algorithm defaults to ``1.5``. * In this implementation, `thresh` defaults (``'auto'``) to flagging the scores with a modified 3-sigma rule

param.label: Algorithm used for calculating the `n`-nearest neighbors
param.help: Algorithm used for calculating the `n`-nearest neighbors

param.label: p
param.help: Degree of the metric ( Minkowski ), according to which the distance to neighbors is determined. Most important values are: * ``1`` - Manhattan Metric * ``2`` - Euclidian Metric

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the window'
param.help: Either given as an Offset String, denoting the window's temporal extension or as an integer, denoting the window's number of periods. ``NaN`` also count as periods. If ``None``, all data points share the same scoring window, which than equals the whole data

param.label: The value the Z-score is tested against
param.help: Defaulting to ``3.5`` (Recommendation of [1])

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Minimum number of valid meassurements in a scoring window, to consider the resulting score valid

param.label: Weather or not to center the target value in the scoring window
param.help: If ``False``, the target value is the last value in the window

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: List of variables names to process
param.help: List of variables names to process

param.label: Transformation to be applied onto every column before scoring
param.help: For more fine-grained control, the data could also be transformed before :py:meth:`~saqc.SaQC.flagMVScores` is called

param.label: alpha
param.help: Level of significance by which it is tested, if an observations score might be drawn from another distribution than the majority of the data

param.label: Number of neighbors included in the scoring process for every datapoint
param.help: Number of neighbors included in the scoring process for every datapoint

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'func'
param.help: Function that aggregates a value's k-smallest distances, returning a scalar score

param.label: iter_start
param.help: Value in ``[0,1]`` that determines which percentage of data is considered normal . 0.5 results in the threshing algorithm to search only the upper 50% of the scores for the cut-off point. (See reference section for more information)

conditional.name: window_cond
conditional.label: Only effective if `threshing` is set to ``'stray'``

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Only effective if `threshing` is set to ``'stray'``'
param.help: Determines the size of the data partitions, the data is decomposed into. Each partition is checked seperately for outliers. Either given as an Offset String, denoting the windows temporal extension or as an integer, denoting the windows number of periods. ``NaN`` also count as periods. If ``None``, all data points share the same scoring window, which than equals the whole data

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Only effective if `threshing` is set to ``'stray'`` and `partition` is an integer. Minimum number of periods per `partition` that have to be present for a valid outlier detection to be made in this partition

param.label: stray_range
param.help: If not ``None``, it is tried to reduce the stray result onto single outlier components of the input `field`. The offset string denotes the range of the temporal surrounding to include into the MAD testing while trying to reduce flags

param.label: Only effective when `stray_range` is not ``None``
param.help: Whether or not to drop flagged values from the temporal surroundings

param.label: Only effective when `stray_range` is not ``None``
param.help: The 'critical' value, controlling wheather the MAD score is considered referring to an outlier or not. Higher values result in less rigid flagging. The default value is widely considered apropriate in the literature

param.label: Only effective when `stray_range` is not ``None``
param.help: Minimum number of measurements necessary in an interval to actually perform the reduction step

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: tolerance
param.help: Maximum difference allowed between the value, directly preceding and the value directly succeeding an offset to trigger flagging of the offsetting values. See condition (4)

param.label: window
param.help: Maximum length allowed for offset value courses, to trigger flagging of the offsetting values. See condition (5). Integer defined window length are only allowed for regularly sampled timeseries

param.label: thresh
param.help: Minimum difference between a value and its successors, to consider the successors an anomalous offset group. See condition (1). If ``None``, condition (1) is not tested

param.label: thresh_relative
param.help: Minimum relative change between a value and its successors, to consider the successors an anomalous offset group. See condition (2). If ``None``, condition (2) is not tested

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: thresh
param.help: The threshold, for the total rise (`thresh` `` 0``), or total drop (`thresh` `` 0``), value courses must not exceed within a timespan of length `raise_window`

param.label: raise_window
param.help: An offset string, determining the timespan, the rise/drop thresholding refers to. Window is inclusively defined

param.label: freq
param.help: An offset string, determining the frequency, the timeseries to flag is supposed to be sampled at. The window is inclusively defined

param.label: See condition (2) of the description given in the Notes
param.help: Window is inclusively defined, defaults to 1.5 times the size of `raise_window`

param.help: See condition (2)

param.help: See condition (3)

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Lower bound for valid data
param.help: Lower bound for valid data

param.label: Upper bound for valid data
param.help: Upper bound for valid data

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Number of periods to be included into the LOF calculation
param.help: Defaults to `20`, which is a value found to be suitable in the literature. * `n` determines the locality of an observation (its `n` nearest neighbors) and sets the upper limit to the number of values in an outlier clusters (i.e. consecutive outliers). Outlier clusters of size greater than `n`/2 may not be detected reliably. * The larger `n`, the lesser the algorithm's sensitivity to local outliers and small or singleton outlier points. Higher values greatly increase numerical costs

param.name: thresh_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Outlier Factor Cutoff'
param.help: * If given, compute local outlier factors and cut them off at value level `thresh`, resulting in all values having factors assigned higher than the cutoff, being flagged

param.label: probability
param.help: Outlier probability cutoff * If given, compute local outlier probabilities and cut them off at value level `probability`, resulting in all values with factors larger than the cutoff, being flagged

conditional.name: corruption_cond
conditional.label: Portion of data that is anomalous

param.name: corruption_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Portion of data that is anomalous'
param.help: Can be given: * as a portion of the data (`float in [0,1]`) * as the total of corrupted samples (`int 1`)

param.label: algorithm
param.help: Algorithm used for calculating the `n`-nearest neighbors needed for LOF calculation

param.label: p
param.help: Degree of the metric ( Minkowski ), according to which distance to neighbors is determined. Most important values are: * ``1`` - Manhatten Metric * ``2`` - Euclidian Metric

conditional.name: density_cond
conditional.label: How to calculate the temporal distance/density for the variable to flag

param.name: density_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'How to calculate the temporal distance/density for the variable to flag'
param.help: * ``'auto'`` - introduces linear density with an increment equal to the median of the absolute diff of the variable to flag. * ``float`` - introduces linear density with an increment equal to `density`

param.label: If True, NaNs in the data are filled with a linear interpolation
param.help: If True, NaNs in the data are filled with a linear interpolation

param.label: slope_correct
param.help: if True, a correction is applied, that removes outlier cluster that actually just seem to be steep slopes

param.label: min_offset
param.help: If set, only those outlier cluster will be flagged, that are preceeded and succeeeded by sufficiently large value jumps . Defaults to estimating the sufficient value jumps from the median over the absolute step sizes between data points

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: List of variables names to process
param.help: List of variables names to process

param.label: method
param.help: Which method to use for ZScoring: * ` standard `: standard Zscoring, using *mean* for the expectation and *standard deviation (std)* as scaling factor * ` modified `: modified Zscoring, using *median* as the expectation and *median absolute deviation (MAD)* as the scaling Factor See notes section for detailed scoring formula

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the window'
param.help: Either determined via an offset string, denoting the windows temporal extension or by an integer, denoting the windows number of periods. ``NaN`` also count as periods. If ``None`` is passed, all data points share the same scoring window, which than equals the whole data

param.label: thresh
param.help: Cutoff level for the Zscores, above which associated points are marked as outliers

param.label: Minimum residual value points must have to be considered outliers
param.help: Minimum residual value points must have to be considered outliers

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Minimum number of valid meassurements in a scoring window, to consider the resulting score valid

param.label: Weather or not to center the target value in the scoring window
param.help: If ``False``, the target value is the last value in the window

param.label: axis
param.help: Along which axis to calculate the scoring statistics: * `0` (default) - calculate statistics along time axis * `1` - calculate statistics over multiple variables See Notes section for a visual clarification of the workings of `axis` and `window`

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: flagPatternByDTW: Pattern Recognition via Dynamic Time Warping

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: The name in `data` which holds the pattern
param.help: The pattern must not have NaNs, have a datetime index and must not be empty

param.label: max_distance
param.help: Maximum dtw-distance between chunk and pattern, if the distance is lower than ``max_distance`` the data gets flagged. With default, ``0.0``, only exact matches are flagged

param.label: If `False`, return unmodified distances
param.help: If `True`, normalize distances by the number of observations of the reference. This helps to make it easier to find a good cutoff threshold for further processing. The distances then refer to the mean distance per datapoint, expressed in the datas units

param.label: plot
param.help: Show a calibration plot, which can be quite helpful to find the right threshold for `max_distance`. It works best with `normalize=True`. Do not use in automatic setups / pipelines. The plot show three lines: - data: the data the function was called on - distances: the calculated distances by the algorithm - indicator: have to distinct levels: `0` and the value of `max_distance`. If `max_distance` is `0.0` it defaults to `1`. Everywhere where the indicator is not `0` the data will be flagged

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

conditional.name: min_length_cond
conditional.label: Minimum temporal extension of value course to qualify as plateau

param.name: min_length_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Minimum temporal extension of value course to qualify as plateau'
param.help: Minimum temporal extension of value course to qualify as plateau

param.name: max_length_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'max_length'
param.help: Maximum temporal extension of value course to qualify as plateau (upper detection limit)

param.label: min_jump
param.help: minimum margin anomalies/plateaus have to differ from directly preceding and succeeding periods. If ``None`` (default), the minimum jump threshold will be derived automatically from the median of the local absolute difference between any two periods in the vicinity of any potential anomaly

param.name: granularity_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'granularity'
param.help: Precision of search: The smaller the better, but also, the more numerically expensive

param.label: flag
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional The flag value the function uses to mark observations. Defaults to the ``BAD`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: concatFlags: Project flags/history of `field` to `target` and adjust to the frequeny grid
resample: Resample data points and flags to a regular frequency

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: target
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: method
param.help: Method to project the flags of `field` to the flags to `target`: * ``'auto'``: invert the last alignment/resampling operation (that is not already inverted) * ``'nagg'``: project a flag of `field` to all timestamps of `target` within the range +/- `freq`/2. * ``'bagg'``: project a flag of `field` to all preceeding timestamps of `target` within the range `freq` * ``'fagg'``: project a flag of `field` to all succeeding timestamps of `target` within the range `freq` * ``'interpolation'`` - project a flag of `field` to all timestamps of `target` within the range +/- `freq` * ``'sshift'`` - same as interpolation * ``'nshift'`` - project a flag of `field` to the neaerest timestamps in `target` within the range +/- `freq`/2 * ``'bshift'`` - project a flag of `field` to nearest preceeding timestamps in `target` * ``'nshift'`` - project a flag of `field` to nearest succeeding timestamps in `target` * ``'match'`` - project a flag of `field` to all identical timestamps `target`

param.label: If True, not the actual method is applied, but its inversion-method
param.help: If True, not the actual method is applied, but its inversion-method

param.name: freq_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Projection range'
param.help: If ``None`` the sampling frequency of `field` is used

validator.message: Please enter a valid Timedelta string (e.g., '30min', '2H', '1D').

param.label: Remove `field` if ``True``
param.help: Remove `field` if ``True``

param.label: squeeze
param.help: Squeeze the history into a single column if ``True``, function specific flag information is lost

param.label: Overwrite existing flags if ``True``
param.help: Overwrite existing flags if ``True``

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: index_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Determines the new index'
param.help: * If an `offset` string: new index will range from start to end of the original index of `field`, exhibting a uniform sampling rate of `idx` * If a `str` that matches a field present in the `SaQC` object, that fields index will be used as new index of `field` * If an `pd.index` object is passed, that will be the new index of `field`

param.label: method
param.help: Determines which of the origins indexes periods to comprise into the calculation of a new flag and a new data value at any period of the new index. * Aggregations Reindexer. Aggregations are data and flags independent, (pure) index selection methods: * `'bagg'`/`'fagg'`: backwards/forwards aggregation . Any new index period gets assigned an aggregation of the values at periods in the original index, that lie between itself and its successor/predecessor. * `'nagg'`: nearest aggregation : Any new index period gets assigned an aggregation of the values at periods in the original index between its direcet predecessor and successor, it is the nearest neighbor to. * Rolling reindexer. Rolling reindexers are equal to aggregations, when projecting between regular and irregular sampling grids forth and back. But due to there simple rolling window construction, they are easier to comprehend, predict and parametrize. On the downside, they are much more expensive computationally and Also, periods can get included in the aggregation to multpiple target periods, (when rolling windows overlap). * `'broll'`/`'froll'`: Any new index period gets assigned an aggregation of all the values at periods of the original index, that fall into a directly preceeding/succeeding window of size `reindex_window`. * Shifts. Shifting methods are shortcuts for aggregation reindex methods, combined with selecting 'last' or 'first' as the `data_aggregation` method. Therefor, both, the `flags_aggregation` and the `data_aggregation` are ignored when using a `shift` reindexer. Also, periods where the data evaluates to `NaN` are dropped before shift index selection. * `'bshift'`/`fshift`: backwards/forwards shift . Any new index period gets assigned the first/last valid (not a data NaN) value it succeeds/preceeds * `'nshift'`: nearest shift : Any new index period gets assigned the value of its closest neighbor in the original index. * Pillar point Mappings. Index selection method designed to select indices suitable for linearly interpolating index values from surrounding pillar points in the original index, or inverting such a selection. Periods where the data evaluates to `NaN`, are dropped from consideration. * `'mshift'`: Merge predecessors and successors. Any new index period gets assigned an aggregation/interpolation comprising the last and the next valid period in the original index. * `'sshift'`: Split -map values onto predecessors and successors. Same as `mshift`, but with a correction that prevents missing value flags from being mapped to continuous data chunk bounds. * Inversion of last method: try to select the method, that * `'invert``

conditional.name: tolerance_cond
conditional.label: Limiting the distance, values can be shifted or comprised into aggregation

param.name: tolerance_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Limiting the distance, values can be shifted or comprised into aggregation'
param.help: Limiting the distance, values can be shifted or comprised into aggregation

validator.message: Please enter a valid Timedelta string (e.g., '30min', '2H', '1D').

param.name: data_aggregation_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'data_aggregation'
param.help: Function string or custom Function, determining how to aggregate new data values from the values at the periods selected according to the `index_selection_method`. If a scalar value is passed, the new data series will just evaluate to that scalar at any new index

param.name: flags_aggregation_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'flags_aggregation'
param.help: Function string or custom Function, determining how to aggregate new flags values from the values at the periods selected according to the `index_selection_method`. If a scalar value is passed, the new flags series will just evaluate to that scalar at any new index

param.label: broadcast
param.help: Weather to propagate aggregation result to full reindex window when using aggregation reindexer. (as opposed to only assign to next/previous/closest)

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: freq_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Offset string'
param.help: Sampling rate of the target frequency grid

validator.message: Please enter a valid Timedelta string (e.g., '30min', '2H', '1D').

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Aggregation function'
param.help: See notes for performance considerations

param.label: Specifies which intervals to be aggregated for a certain timestamp
param.help: (preceding, succeeding or surrounding interval). See description above for more details

param.label: Maximum number of allowed ``NaN``s in a resampling interval
param.help: If exceeded, the aggregation of the interval evaluates to ``NaN``

param.label: Same as `maxna` but for consecutive NaNs
param.help: Same as `maxna` but for consecutive NaNs

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: calculatePolynomialResiduals: Fits a polynomial model to the data and calculate the residuals
calculateRollingResiduals: Calculate the diff of a rolling-window function and the data

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

conditional.name: window_cond
conditional.label: The size of the window you want to use for fitting

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'The size of the window you want to use for fitting'
param.help: If an integer is passed, the size refers to the number of periods for every fitting window. If an offset string is passed, the size refers to the total temporal extension. The window will be centered around the vaule-to-be-fitted. For regularly sampled timeseries the period number will be casted down to an odd number if even

param.label: The degree of the polynomial used for fitting
param.help: The degree of the polynomial used for fitting

param.label: min_periods
param.help: The minimum number of periods, that has to be available in every values fitting surrounding for the polynomial fit to be performed. If there are not enough values, np.nan gets assigned. Default (0) results in fitting regardless of the number of values present (results in overfitting for too sparse intervals). To automatically set the minimum number of periods to the number of values in an offset defined window size, pass np.nan

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

conditional.name: window_cond
conditional.label: The size of the window you want to roll with

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'The size of the window you want to roll with'
param.help: If an integer is passed, the size refers to the number of periods for every fitting window. If an offset string is passed, the size refers to the total temporal extension. For regularly sampled timeseries, the period number will be casted down to an odd number if ``center=True``

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'func'
param.help: default mean Function to roll with

param.label: The minimum number of periods to get a valid value

param.label: If True, center the rolling window
param.help: If True, center the rolling window

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: rolling: Calculate a rolling-window function on the data

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

conditional.name: window_cond
conditional.label: The size of the window you want to roll with

param.name: window_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'The size of the window you want to roll with'
param.help: If an integer is passed, the size refers to the number of periods for every fitting window. If an offset string is passed, the size refers to the total temporal extension. For regularly sampled timeseries, the period number will be casted down to an odd number if ``center=True``

param.name: target_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'target'
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` , optional Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'func'
param.help: default mean Function to roll with

param.label: The minimum number of periods to get a valid value
param.help: The minimum number of periods to get a valid value

param.label: If True, center the rolling window
param.help: If True, center the rolling window

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: assignKNNScore: Score datapoints by an aggregation of the distances to their `k` nearest neighbors
assignUniLOF: Assign univariate Local Outlier Factor (LOF) or inivariate Local Outlier Probability (LOP)

param.label: List of variables names to process
param.help: List of variables names to process

param.label: target
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: n
param.help: : The number of nearest neighbors to which the distance is comprised in every datapoints scoring calculation

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'func'
param.help: default sum A function that assigns a score to every one dimensional array, containing the distances to every datapoints `n` nearest neighbors

param.name: freq_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'freq'
param.help: Determines the segmentation of the data into partitions, the kNN algorithm is applied onto individually. * ``np.inf``: Apply Scoring on whole data set at once * ``x`` 0 : Apply scoring on successive data chunks of periods length ``x`` * Offset String : Apply scoring on successive partitions of temporal extension matching the passed offset string

param.label: min_periods
param.help: The minimum number of periods that have to be present in a window for the kNN scoring to be applied. If the number of periods present is below `min_periods`, the score for the datapoints in that window will be np.nan

param.label: The search algorithm to find each datapoints k nearest neighbors
param.help: The keyword just gets passed on to the underlying sklearn method. See reference [1] for more information on the algorithm

param.label: The metric the distances to any datapoints neighbors is computed with
param.help: The default of `metric` together with the default of `p` result in the euclidian to be applied. The keyword just gets passed on to the underlying sklearn method. See reference [1] for more information on the algorithm

param.label: p
param.help: : The grade of the metrice specified by parameter `metric`. The keyword just gets passed on to the underlying sklearn method. See reference [1] for more information on the algorithm

param.label: List of variables names to process
param.help: List of variables names to process

param.label: target
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: Number of periods to be included into the LOF calculation
param.help: Defaults to `20`, which is a value found to be suitable in the literature

param.name: freq_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'freq'
param.help: Determines the segmentation of the data into partitions, the kNN algorithm is applied onto individually

param.label: algorithm
param.help: Algorithm used for calculating the `n`-nearest neighbors needed for LOF calculation

param.label: p
param.help: Degree of the metric ( Minkowski ), according to wich distance to neighbors is determined. Most important values are: * `1` - Manhatten Metric * `2` - Euclidian Metric

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Number of periods to be included into the LOF calculation
param.help: Defaults to `20`, which is a value found to be suitable in the literature. * `n` determines the locality of an observation (its `n` nearest neighbors) and sets the upper limit of values of an outlier clusters (i.e. consecutive outliers). Outlier clusters of size greater than `n/2` may not be detected reliably. * The larger `n`, the lesser the algorithm's sensitivity to local outliers and small or singleton outliers points. Higher values greatly increase numerical costs

param.label: algorithm
param.help: Algorithm used for calculating the `n`-nearest neighbors needed for LOF calculation

param.label: p
param.help: Degree of the metric ( Minkowski ), according to wich distance to neighbors is determined. Most important values are: * `1` - Manhatten Metric * `2` - Euclidian Metric

conditional.name: density_cond
conditional.label: How to calculate the temporal distance/density for the variable-to-be-flagged

param.name: density_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'How to calculate the temporal distance/density for the variable-to-be-flagged'
param.help: * float - introduces linear density with an increment equal to `density` * Callable - calculates the density by applying the function passed onto the variable to be flagged (passed as Series)

param.label: If True, NaNs in the data are filled with a linear interpolation
param.help: If True, NaNs in the data are filled with a linear interpolation

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Size of the window
param.help: can be determined as: * Offset String, denoting the windows temporal extension * Integer, denoting the windows number of periods. * `None` (default), All data points share the same scoring window, which than equals the whole data

param.name: norm_func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'norm_func'
param.help: default mean Function to calculate the scaling for every window

param.name: model_func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'model_func'
param.help: default std Function to calculate the center moment in every window

param.label: Weather or not to center the target value in the scoring window
param.help: If `False`, the target value is the last value in the window

param.label: min_periods
param.help: Minimum number of valid meassurements in a scoring window, to consider the resulting score valid

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: copyField: Make a copy of the data and flags of `field`
dropField: Drops field from the data and flags
flagByClick: Pop up GUI for adding or removing flags by selection of points in the data plot
plot: Plot data and flags or store plot to file
renameField: Rename field in data and flags

param.name: field_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Variable to process'
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: target_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'target'
param.help: :py:class:`SaQCFields` | :py:class:`newSaQCFields` Variable name to which the results are written. `target` will be created if it does not exist. Defaults to `field`

param.label: overwrite
param.help: overwrite target, if already existant

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: max_gap
param.help: If ``None``, all data points will be connected, resulting in long linear lines, in case of large data gaps. ``NaN`` values will be removed before plotting. If an offset string is passed, only points that have a distance below ``max_gap`` are connected via the plotting line

param.label: gui_mode
param.help: * `` GUI `` (default), spawns TK based pop-up GUI, enabling scrolling and binding for subplots * `` overlay ``, spawns matplotlib based pop-up GUI. May be less conflicting, but does not support scrolling or binding

param.label: dfilter
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional Defines which observations will be masked based on the already existing flags. Any data point with a flag equal or worse to this threshold will be passed as ``NaN`` to the function. Defaults to the ``DFILTER_ALL`` value of the translation scheme

param.name: field_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Variable to process'
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: path
param.help: If ``None`` is passed, interactive mode is entered; plots are shown immediatly and a user need to close them manually before execution continues. If a filepath is passed instead, store-mode is entered and the plot is stored unter the passed location

param.label: max_gap
param.help: If ``None``, all data points will be connected, resulting in long linear lines, in case of large data gaps. ``NaN`` values will be removed before plotting. If an offset string is passed, only points that have a distance below ``max_gap`` are connected via the plotting line

param.name: mode_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'mode'
param.help: How to process multiple variables to be plotted: * ` oneplot ` : plot all variables with their flags in one axis (default) * ` subplots ` : generate subplot grid where each axis contains one variable plot with associated flags * ` biplot ` : plotting first and second variable in field against each other in a scatter plot (point cloud)

conditional.name: history_cond
conditional.label: Discriminate the plotted flags with respect to the tests they originate from

param.name: history_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Discriminate the plotted flags with respect to the tests they originate from'
param.help: * `` valid ``: Only plot flags, that are not overwritten by subsequent tests. Only list tests in the legend, that actually contributed flags to the overall result. * ``None``: Just plot the resulting flags for one variable, without any historical and/or meta information. * list of strings: List of tests. Plot flags from the given tests, only. * ``complete`` (not recommended, deprecated): Plot all the flags set by any test, independently from them being removed or modified by subsequent modifications. (this means: plotted flags do not necessarily match with flags ultimately assigned to the data)

conditional.name: xscope_cond
conditional.label: Determine a chunk of the data to be plotted

param.name: xscope_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Determine a chunk of the data to be plotted'
param.help: ``xscope`` can be anything, that is a valid argument to the ``pandas.Series.__getitem__`` method

param.name: xscope_start
param.label: Determine a chunk of the data to be plotted (start index)
param.help: Start index of the slice (e.g., 0).

param.name: xscope_end
param.label: Determine a chunk of the data to be plotted (end index)
param.help: End index of the slice (exclusive).

param.name: yscope_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'yscope'
param.help: Either a tuple of 2 scalars that determines all plots' y-view limits, or a list of those tuples, determining the different variables y-view limits (must match number of variables) or a dictionary with variables as keys and the y-view tuple as values

param.name: key
param.label: Key
param.help: Name of the dictionary key.

param.name: value
param.label: Value
param.help: Value for the key (e.g., 'min,max').

param.label: dfilter
param.help: :py:class:`Any`, optional Defines which observations will be masked based on the already existing flags. Any data point with a flag equal or worse to this threshold will be passed as ``NaN`` to the function. Defaults to the ``DFILTER_ALL`` value of the translation scheme

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: String, field is to be replaced with
param.help: String, field is to be replaced with

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.label: The masking mode
param.help: - periodic : parameters period_start , end are evaluated to generate a periodical mask - mask_var : data[mask_var] is expected to be a boolean valued timeseries and is used as mask

param.label: selection_field
param.help: Only effective if mode == mask_var Fieldname of the column, holding the data that is to be used as mask. (must be boolean series) Neither the series` length nor its labels have to match data[field]`s index and length. An inner join of the indices will be calculated and values get masked where the values of the inner join are ``True``

param.label: start
param.help: Only effective if mode == seasonal String denoting starting point of every period. Formally, it has to be a truncated instance of mm-ddTHH:MM:SS . Has to be of same length as `end` parameter. See examples section below for some examples

param.label: end
param.help: Only effective if mode == periodic String denoting starting point of every period. Formally, it has to be a truncated instance of mm-ddTHH:MM:SS . Has to be of same length as `end` parameter. See examples section below for some examples

param.label: Wheather or not to include the mask defining bounds to the mask
param.help: Wheather or not to include the mask defining bounds to the mask

param.name: method_select
param.label: Method
param.option: transform: Transform data by applying a custom function on data chunks of variable size. Existing flags are preserved

param.label: Variable to process
param.help: Variable to process

param.name: func_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Transformation function'
param.help: Transformation function

param.name: freq_selector
param.label: Choose type for 'Size of the data window'
param.help: The transformation is applied on each window individually * ``None``: Apply transformation on the entire data set at once * ``int`` : Apply transformation on successive data chunks of the given length. Must be grater than 0. * Offset String : Apply transformation on successive data chunks of the given temporal extension

tool.help: This tool provides access to SaQC functions for quality control of time series data.
